trans-unit.source: Certificate assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Certificate assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Certificates can be stored securely in Azure Automation so they can be accessed by runbooks to authenticate against Azure and third party resources. This article explains the details of certificates and how to work with them in both textual and graphical authoring.
trans-unit.target: Certificates can be stored securely in Azure Automation so they can be accessed by runbooks to authenticate against Azure and third party resources. This article explains the details of certificates and how to work with them in both textual and graphical authoring.

trans-unit.source: Certificates can be stored securely in Azure Automation so they can be accessed by runbooks using the Get-AutomationCertificate activity.
trans-unit.target: Certificates can be stored securely in Azure Automation so they can be accessed by runbooks using the Get-AutomationCertificate activity.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to create runbooks that use certificates for authentication or adds them to Azure or third party resources that your runbook may be creating or configuring.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to create runbooks that use certificates for authentication or adds them to Azure or third party resources that your runbook may be creating or configuring.

trans-unit.source: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.
trans-unit.target: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.

trans-unit.source: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.
trans-unit.target: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.

trans-unit.source: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.
trans-unit.target: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage automation certificate assets with Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage automation certificate assets with Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.
trans-unit.target: They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.

trans-unit.source: Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Retrieves information about a certificate.
trans-unit.target: Retrieves information about a certificate.

trans-unit.source: You can only retrieve the certificate itself from Get-AutomationCertificate activity.
trans-unit.target: You can only retrieve the certificate itself from Get-AutomationCertificate activity.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New- AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New- AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Imports a new certificate into Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: Imports a new certificate into Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Remove- AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Remove- AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Removes a certificate from Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: Removes a certificate from Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set- AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set- AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Sets the properties for an existing certificate including uploading the certificate file and setting the password for a .pfx.
trans-unit.target: Sets the properties for an existing certificate including uploading the certificate file and setting the password for a .pfx.

trans-unit.source: The activities in the following table are used to access certificates in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The activities in the following table are used to access certificates in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: Activities
trans-unit.target: Activities

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Get-AutomationCertificate
trans-unit.target: Get-AutomationCertificate

trans-unit.source: Gets a certificate to use in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: Gets a certificate to use in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of GetAutomationCertificate since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and certificate assets at design time.
trans-unit.target: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of GetAutomationCertificate since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and certificate assets at design time.

trans-unit.source: When you create a new certificate, you upload a cer or pfx file to Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: When you create a new certificate, you upload a cer or pfx file to Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: If you mark the certificate as exportable, then you can transfer it out of the Azure Automation certificate store.
trans-unit.target: If you mark the certificate as exportable, then you can transfer it out of the Azure Automation certificate store.

trans-unit.source: If it is not exportable, then it can only be used for signing within the runbook.
trans-unit.target: If it is not exportable, then it can only be used for signing within the runbook.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Credential.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Credential.

trans-unit.source: In the Credential Type dropdown, select Certificate.
trans-unit.target: In the Credential Type dropdown, select Certificate.

trans-unit.source: Type a name for the certificate in the Name box and click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: Type a name for the certificate in the Name box and click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: Browse for a .cer or .pfx file.
trans-unit.target: Browse for a .cer or .pfx file.

trans-unit.source: If you select a .pfx file, specify a password and whether it should be allowed to be exported.
trans-unit.target: If you select a .pfx file, specify a password and whether it should be allowed to be exported.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark to upload the certificate file and save the new certificate asset.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark to upload the certificate file and save the new certificate asset.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.

trans-unit.source: Click the Certificates part to open the Certificates blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Certificates part to open the Certificates blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Add a certificate at the top of the blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Add a certificate at the top of the blade.

trans-unit.source: Type a name for the certificate in the Name box.
trans-unit.target: Type a name for the certificate in the Name box.

trans-unit.source: Click Select a file under Upload a certificate file to browse for a .cer or .pfx file.
trans-unit.target: Click Select a file under Upload a certificate file to browse for a .cer or .pfx file.

trans-unit.source: If you select a .pfx file, specify a password and whether it should be allowed to be exported.
trans-unit.target: If you select a .pfx file, specify a password and whether it should be allowed to be exported.

trans-unit.source: Click Create to save the new certificate asset.
trans-unit.target: Click Create to save the new certificate asset.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to create a new automation certificate and marks it exportable.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to create a new automation certificate and marks it exportable.

trans-unit.source: This imports an existing pfx file.
trans-unit.target: This imports an existing pfx file.

trans-unit.source: You must use the Get-AutomationCertificate activity to use a certificate in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: You must use the Get-AutomationCertificate activity to use a certificate in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: You cannot use the <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title> cmdlet since it returns information about the certificate asset but not the certificate itself.
trans-unit.target: You cannot use the <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationCertificate</linkText><title></title> cmdlet since it returns information about the certificate asset but not the certificate itself.

trans-unit.source: The following sample code shows how to add a certificate to a cloud service in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following sample code shows how to add a certificate to a cloud service in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, the password is retrieved from an encrypted automation variable.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, the password is retrieved from an encrypted automation variable.

trans-unit.source: You add a Get-AutomationCerticiate to a graphical runbook by right-clicking on the certificate in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting Add to canvas.
trans-unit.target: You add a Get-AutomationCerticiate to a graphical runbook by right-clicking on the certificate in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting Add to canvas.

trans-unit.source: The following image shows an example of using a certificate in a graphical runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows an example of using a certificate in a graphical runbook.

trans-unit.source: This is the same example shown above for adding a certificate to a cloud service from a textual runbook.
trans-unit.target: This is the same example shown above for adding a certificate to a cloud service from a textual runbook.

trans-unit.source: This example uses the UseConnectionObject parameter set for the Send-TwilioSMS activity that uses a connection object for authentication to the service.
trans-unit.target: This example uses the UseConnectionObject parameter set for the Send-TwilioSMS activity that uses a connection object for authentication to the service.

trans-unit.source: A <linkText>pipeline link</linkText><title></title> must be used here since a sequence link would return a collection containing containing a single object which the Connection parameter is not expecting.
trans-unit.target: A <linkText>pipeline link</linkText><title></title> must be used here since a sequence link would return a collection containing containing a single object which the Connection parameter is not expecting.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Links in graphical authoring</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Links in graphical authoring</linkText><title></title>
